s.text: That message-to-home aspect of Tocqueville's work is important in understanding its limitations.
That message-to-home aspect of Tocqueville's work is important in understanding its limitations.
"Nothing strikes a European traveler in the United States more," wrote Tocqueville, "than the absence of what we would call government or administration.
"Nothing strikes a European traveler in the United States more," wrote Tocqueville, "than the absence of what we would call government or administration.
Yet, blinded by his negative passions about state power in France, Tocqueville failed to grasp what his observations meant about the early American state.

Social historian Richard D. Brown emphasizes that the Revolution, political struggles over the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, and deepening popular participation in national, state, and local elections served to spur associational life.

After all, one of Democracy in America 's insights was that vital democratic participation served as a kind of "school," where Americans learned how to build social and civic associations of all sorts.

But apart from a few on the right--notably the National Right to Life Committee, the Christian Coalition, and the National Rifle Association--the few new big voluntary associations that have been founded have been structured like thousands of smaller ones: They are staff-led, mailing-list associations.

He would also surely be surprised that today's conservatives are using his Democracy in America to justify a depoliticized and romantic localism as an improbable remedy for the larger ills of national politics.

The great women's federations of the early 20 th century were champions of local, state, and federal regulations, services, and benefits for mothers and children.

Given Tocqueville's anti-statist purposes, it is not surprising that contemporary critics of the U.S. federal government celebrate the great Frenchman's stress on voluntary associations (understood as functioning in opposition to bureaucratic state power).

This has happened in electoral politics at the same time that all our mailboxes are full of computer-generated mailings from single-issue advocacy groups seeking to raise money from paper "memberships."
The Grand Army of the Republic spread in the wake of state and national benefits for Union veterans of the Civil War, for example.
